title: This Gen-Z Founder Turned Her Side Hustle Into a $10 Million Brand—and Made Paige DeSorbo a Fan
description: Gia Mezz, founder of clothing brand Leau, taught herself paid marketing on a bootstrapped budget.
content:
With about $20,000 of her savings, Gia Mezz launched her clothing brand, Leau, as a self-funded side hustle in June 2020. But for the first few months, she kept her burgeoning e-commerce business a secret. Feeling weighed down by imposter syndrome and worried she might fail as a first-time founder in her mid-20s, Mezz didn’t tell her friends or even her mom about what she was working on. Instead, she just kept plugging away at her day job at a fashion startup in Los Angeles. Then, one conversation at work proved she was on to something.

One of Mezz’s co-workers sent her a message, she recalls: “I keep seeing this brand come across my Instagram ads. I’m looking for a dress. What do you think?” It was from her brand.



“It was just so crazy,” says Mezz, now 29. “I was doing something right.” Digital ads gradually fallen out of favor since the infamous 2021 Apple iOS update restricted brands’ ability to use third-party cookies to track consumers for advertising purposes. That change made it far more costly for brands to see any positive impact from social media ads—much less the same impact they saw pre-update. As digital marketing costs have kept climbing, companies have been strapped by shrinking budgets and mandates to find more places to cut.



This has not phased Mezz. Digital ads have remained a growth engine for Leau, which primarily spends on Google, Meta, Pinterest, and, increasingly, TikTok. The strategy requires a hefty upfront cost. Mezz estimates she spent over $100,000 on digital ads during her first year of business alone, floating those charges on her American Express card.

Still, the investment has paid off. Leau, which has grown to five employees, including Mezz’s mom and stepfather, is profitable and has exceeded $10 million in lifetime sales. This year, the clothing company has already surpassed $3.1 million in revenue and expects to finish the year around $5 million. After paying off her credit card bill and producing the next batch of dresses, blazers, corsets, and tops, the rest of that money goes straight back into Leaus’s digital advertising budget. “I used myself as a baseline of who to target,” says Mezz, who says she taught herself how to use the platforms’ ad systems through free tutorials on YouTube and through incremental trial and error experimentation, seeing what resonated with shoppers—and what didn’t. “At the beginning, I started off with $5 here, $5 there, and I just kept doubling my budgets, which I think really contributed to scaling the brand so fast.” That ad strategy even hooked Paige DeSorbo. The former Bravo star turned podcaster turned entrepreneur, who launched her sleepwear and loungewear brand Daphne earlier this summer, discovered Leau from an Instagram ad. DeSorbo, who is known for her love of fashion, bought three items, and then posted about her haul on her Instagram story, tagging Leau in the video.

Initially, Mezz kept her business a secret and kept it a secret. However, a conversation at work convinced her, with a message from a co-worker stating that she was on to something. Mezz then began using digital advertising, which she believes has remained a growth engine for the brand. She estimates she spent over $100,000 on digital ads during her first year of business alone, floating these charges on her American Express card. Despite the increase in digital marketing costs, Mez remains committed to the brand, which has surpassed $3.1 million in revenue this year.

argos_summary: Gia Mezz launched her clothing brand, Leau, in June 2020 with $20,000 in savings, initially keeping it a secret due to imposter syndrome. Despite rising digital ad costs post-2021 Apple iOS update, her strategic investment in online advertising has led to significant growth, with Leau achieving over $10 million in lifetime sales and a projected $5 million in revenue for the year. Mezz's self-taught ad strategies and targeted marketing have successfully propelled her brand, which now employs five people, including family members.
